por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report

To address low and declining graduation rates, LeTourneau University's School of Engineering and Engineering Technology (SEET) implemented retention initiatives that included (1) the development of a coordinated faculty-peer mentoring program for first-year students, (2) a new two-course sequence with the primary aim of stimulating first-year student interest and engagement through early exposure to real-world, multidisciplinary engineering practice, (3) contact with practicing engineers, and (4) a remodeling of a first semester “Intro to College” course to target the needs of engineering students.  The improvements comprised the core of an effort to retain students already matriculated within the SEET, rather than to recruit them away from other STEM disciplines. 

During the first six years of implementation of the First-Year Initiatives for Retention Enhancement (FIRE) project, retention and graduation rates improved considerably.  The project began with a partial deployment in the fall of 2010, at which time 1-year retention was at 70%.  Six years later, the 2015 cohort 1-year retention rate was 85% for “first time in college” (FTIC) students meeting the project target of 85%, and becoming the highest ever recorded for the school.  Although the increase fluctuated over those years, as seen in the accompanying retention graph, the trend indicated an average increase in retention of 7.5% over the historic baseline suggesting a significant positive project impact.  The only 6-year graduation rate data point at the end of the grant period, indicated an increase from 42% to 54%.  While this did not yet meet the project goal of 65%, the higher 1-year retention rates are expected to result in higher graduation rates in the upcoming years.  

Intellectual Merit

In terms of the retention initiatives themselves, this project again confirmed the effectiveness of two of the best practices cited in the publications addressing strategies for improving engineering education retention.   First-Year Interest Groups (FIGs), where freshmen are put into small mentoring groups of like-majors, along with a student and faculty mentor, were the most positive aspect of the program, as indicated in project participant assessment surveys.   Secondly, the first-year engineering practice courses achieved their goal of helping students understand and embrace the engineering profession, as indicated in course pre- and post-surveys.

Broader Impacts

One of the outcomes of the improved graduation rate that resulted from this project was an increase in the graduates entering the high-tech workforce, and therefore some reduction in the demand for imported labor in the engineering field improving the nation’s competitiveness in the global economy.  The strategies implemented also proved effective in increasing the retention of female students in engineering and technology, and therefore increased their presence in the workforce.

 The dissemination of this project through national and local forums has provided a transfer of knowledge and experience to similar institutions seeking to improve retention. Moreover, the project has inspired the creativity and persistence of first-year SEET students through relevant experiences and collaborative learning that will have a lasting positive effect on the quality and effectiveness of a program already marked by excellence in “learning by doing” at LeTourneau University.

  

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2017
Modified by: Alan Niemi

The improvements comprised the core of an effort to retain students already matriculated within the SEET, rather than to recruit them away from other STEM disciplines.  

During the first six years of implementation of the First-Year Initiatives for Retention Enhancement (FIRE) project, retention and graduation rates improved considerably.  The project began with a partial deployment in the fall of 2010, at which time 1-year retention was at 70%.  Six years later, the 2015 cohort 1-year retention rate was 85% for "first time in college" (FTIC) students meeting the project target of 85%, and becoming the highest ever recorded for the school. In terms of the retention initiatives themselves, this project again confirmed the effectiveness of two of the best practices cited in the publications addressing strategies for improving engineering education retention.   First-Year Interest Groups (FIGs), where freshmen are put into small mentoring groups of like-majors, along with a student and faculty mentor, were the most positive aspect of the program, as indicated in project participant assessment surveys.   Secondly, the first-year engineering practice courses achieved their goal of helping students understand and embrace the engineering profession, as indicated in course pre- and post-surveys.

One of the outcomes of the improved graduation rate that resulted from this project was an increase in the graduates entering the high-tech workforce, and therefore some reduction in the demand for imported labor in the engineering field improving the nation?s competitiveness in the global economy.  The strategies implemented also proved effective in increasing the retention of female students in engineering and technology, and therefore increased their presence in the workforce. 

 The dissemination of this project through national and local forums has provided a transfer of knowledge and experience to similar institutions seeking to improve retention. Moreover, the project has inspired the creativity and persistence of first-year SEET students through relevant experiences and collaborative learning that will have a lasting positive effect on the quality and effectiveness of a program already marked by excellence in "learning by doing" at LeTourneau University.
